results.name: The ‘Australian' alps
results.description: These feature films and documentaries show how stories have been told to lay claim - and reclaim - the land and our national identity.

key_work.title: Ngaya (I Am)
key_work.credit_line:
With Rhian Hinkley and composer Harry Covill

Commissioned by ACMI
key_work.brief_description:
“Ngaya (I Am) is a cut-and-paste, punked-up look at my Country. It looks at Country from an insider-outsider perspective… and uses humour to disarm the viewer about the true nature of invasion.”

Shirtless men dance under a mirror ball and a jet ski skims flood waters as Ngarigo Country burns. Peter Waples-Crowe layers footage from tourism campaigns, ads for the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme and amateur YouTube movies, as well as newly recorded video and animations of his distinctive paintings. These visions of Ngarigo Country are collaged atop colonial paintings, including Eugene von Guérard’s “North-east view from the northern top of Mount Kosciusko” (1863).

Paintings like this perpetuated the myth of terra nullius, and Peter’s work dismantles the legacy of erasure and misrepresentation by interrogating the way non-Indigenous people construct images of Aboriginal land and people. Through this searing yet playful contrast, he mocks non-Indigenous visions of Country that view it as something to be stolen, owned and exploited – nothing but ski slopes and untapped riches.

As someone who views his Country from afar, Peter repurposes these fragmented images to piece together the multiple layers of his identity – proudly inserting them back into the landscape and proclaiming, ‘We are still here’.

start.title: The Man from Snowy River
start.creator_credit: George Miller and Geoff Burrowes
start.brief_description: The Man From Snowy River, based on the classic Australian poem by Banjo Patterson, tells the story of an 18 year old boy who proves himself a man during an unforgettable chase on horseback down the rugged Snowy Mountains and becomes a legend. The most magnificent footage of horses ever filmed.

end.title: The Silver brumby
end.creator_credit: John Tatoulis, Colin South and Media World Features
end.brief_description: Based on Elyne Mitchell’s famous novel, “The Silver Brumby” is set in the Australian Alps, where a rogue stallion is king of the mob of horses which roam the awesome landscape. For years, the mountain men have tried to capture him, but with no success. One horseman is determined to succeed where others have failed and embarks on an unforgettable adventure. Starring Russell Crowe, Caroline Goodall and Ami Daemion.

links.description: The The Silver Brumby is set in the “Victorian High country”. Based on an old fable about the prince of the brumbies, the film follows one man’s impossible wish to tame the young stallion, Thowra. Like The Man from Snowy River is represents how settlers have tried to control the environment.

links.description: The bushranger is essential to the construction of Australia’s national identity. Kirk Dougla’s character exemplifies this in The Man from Snowy River with his rugged battle against the natural world. The mountains and bush are something to be tamed, a triumph of strength and masculinity - something that The Legend of Molly Johnson tries to counter.

end.title: The Snowy : A Dream of Growing Up
end.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Siobhan McHugh and Film Australia
end.brief_description: Australia’s Snowy Mountains Scheme is one of the world’s greatest engineering feats. The project to bring water to the dry west was built between 1949 and 1974, employing 100,000 people, many of them migrants who brought with them changes that have shaped Australia. This film documents Australia’s ambitious project using interviews and historical film. Based on the book “The Snowy : the People Behind the Power” by Siobhan McHugh.

constellations_other.name: The ‘Australian' alps

links.description: The natural world as something to conquer and a signifier of progress is also captured in documentaries. The Snowy: a Dream of Growing Up tells the story of the 100,000 mostly immigrant workers who constructed the Snowy Mountain Hydro Scheme, one of the largest engineering feats in the world today.

links.description: Peter Waples-Crow’s Ngaya (I Am) critiques the conflicting narratives of Ngarigu country in mass media in his signature style, from skiing commercials to hunting videos, asking, whose mountain is it anyway? Goa-Gunggari-Wakka Wakka Murri woman Leah Purcel’s The Legend of Molly Johnson is also set in the region and reclaims the bushranger through an Indigenous lens.

end.title: Jindabyne
end.creator_credit: Ray Lawrence, Catherine Jarmar and April Films
end.brief_description: Based on the Raymond Carver short story “So much water so close to home”, this is a compelling drama about a marriage drawn asunder by a young girl’s murder. Stewart Kane, played by Irish actor Gabrielle Byrne, goes fishing with friends to a remote spot; when he and his friends find a young girl’s mutilated body they continue with their trip, reporting the crime upon their return. Such callousness makes Claire (Laura Linney) question her marriage and her husband’s humanity and she is drawn into a web of intrigue and ethical dilemmas. Expanding upon Carver’s original text, Lawrence examines Aboriginal rites and ceremonies and places, central to the narrative, the uncomfortable relationship between the black and white communities.

constellations_other.name: The ‘Australian' alps

links.description: In Jindabyne, an Indigenous woman’s body is discovered by a group of fishermen, who delay reporting the crime to the police. Jindabye is filmed entirely on location in the town of the same name, situated right next to the Snowy Mountains, and also features Leah Purcell as Carol.

results.name: Extraction
results.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

key_work.title: DIGGERMODE
key_work.brief_description:
“Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction and storage, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind-the-servers look into how memory works within platform capitalism.”

“DIGGERMODE” questions the social and environmental ethics of technology in constructing, storing and sharing our images, whether in surveillance databases, museum archives or online. With artificial intelligence (AI), Joel Sherwood Spring has created landscapes in the style of acclaimed Arrernte artist Albert Namatjira being torn apart by mining machinery, and has trained another AI to answer questions like “Who’s your Mob?” Presumably, anyone could do this – but should anyone be able to appropriate Indigenous art from the internet? How do we protect our knowledges in digital spaces? Can sand used to make silicon microchips contain memories of Country?

Joel’s work confronts the viewer with uncomfortable and overlooked aspects of our hyper-networked age, grounding the possibilities of ‘the cloud’ and AI in the broader context of ongoing colonisation. The work considers the environmental damage caused by new technology and data storage, and how it is Indigenous peoples whose lands and ways of being are profoundly impacted by capitalism’s extractive processes.

links.description: Joel Shwerwood Spring’s DIGGERMODE collages archival and new footage to interrogate how First Nations stories are held in archives. The Last Angel of History follows a “data thief” who travels through time and space searching for a “crossroads”, where he makes archaeological digs for fragments of history and new sciences. The film uses archival footage to explore black creativity as a technology.

end.title: Three Thousand
end.creator_credit: Asinnajaq, Annie Jean, Kat Baulu and ONF | NFB
end.brief_description: Inuit artist Asinnajaq plunges us into a sublime imaginary universe—14 minutes of luminescent, archive-inspired cinema that recast the present, past and future of her people in a radiant new light. Diving into the NFB’s vast archive, she parses the complicated cinematic representation of the Inuit, harvesting fleeting truths and fortuitous accidents from a range of sources—newsreels, propaganda, ethnographic docs, and work by Indigenous filmmakers. Embedding historic footage into original animation, she conjures up a vision of hope and beautiful possibility.

constellations_other.name: Extraction
constellations_other.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

links.description: Three Thousand is a short film made by Inuk artist Asinnajaq that uses archival footage of her own people. Critical of the role institutions have in constructing and disseminating harmful representations of native peoples, it juxtaposes new footage and found archival footage to create a vision of hopeful possibility.

end.title: Rodeo Baby!
end.creator_credit: Jazz Money
end.brief_description:
“The artwork is centred upon the belief that it is our own bodies that are the truest archive of our experience and that any documentation is only ever an approximation of the person doing the gazing – not the gazed.”

While trawling archival video material, Jazz Money discovered an overwhelming amount of footage of First Peoples in rodeos. There was the joy of seeing Blak faces, but an unease in knowing non-Indigenous voyeurs likely captured the footage. In the vast network of archives in this country’s institutions, photos and videos of First Peoples are filed away, with the people who have been recorded – often unknowingly – and their descendants unaware the recordings exist.

Jazz reclaims these images, combining them with stills from film and TV, including “The Phantom Stockman” (1953), “Radiance” (1998) and” The Drover’s Wife” (2021), in this large-scale photographic essay. It celebrates First Peoples representation and the Aboriginal scholars who critique this colonial hoarding, giving new meaning to images that have been dislocated by archival practices. Jazz asks, “If these archival collections are the rodeo, who is playing cowboy with our images?”

end.brief_description: In 1825, Claire, a young Irish convict, enlists an Indigenous tracker to chase a British soldier through the rugged Tasmanian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

links.description: Before Cate Blanchett played Hepburn, she was expertly edited by fellow Australian Jill Bilcock in Elizabeth. Famous for her keen eye for performance, Bilcock chose to edit the film around Blancett’s strongest scenes.

Francis left Warner Bros after the Independent Theater Owners of America published a list of actors they deemed “box office poison.” Francis revived her career in part due to extensive war-zone touring, which Four Jills in a Jeep used as inspiration.

start.brief_description: In 1954, Marilyn Monroe went on strike. Instead of starring in another musical comedy from 20th Century Fox, Monroe courted the mainstream media by honeymooning with a famous baseballer. The news made her a star, which she used to renegotiate her contract and secure more daring roles.

links.description: Highly sort after for her editing prowess Jill Bilcock has had a prolific career overseas and at home, including High Ground, which reimagines the events surrounding Gan Gan Massacre of 1919 in Arnhem Land and features First Nations actor Magnolia Maymuru in her second role.

start.brief_description: In 1825, Claire, a young Irish convict, enlists an Indigenous tracker to chase a British soldier through the rugged Tasmanian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

results.name: Breaking the Hays Code
results.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

key_work.title: From scandal to censorship
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Concerned that movies promoted loose morals, and scandalised by tabloid stories of stars behaving badly, religious and civic groups lobbied the studios to clean up their act. To avoid government censorship, the industry responded with the Motion Picture Production Code.

constellations_primary.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_primary.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

start.title: The World Moves On
start.creator_credit: John Ford, Fox Film Corporation and Reginald Berkeley
start.brief_description: Two families, cotton merchants in England and America, with branches in France and Prussia swear to stand by each other in a belief that a great business firmly established in four countries will be able to withstand even such another calamity as the Napoleonic Wars from which Europe is slowly recovering. Then many years later, along comes World War One and the years that follow, to test the businesses.

end.title: To Have and Have Not
end.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Milo Anderson, Christian Nyby, Warner Bros. Pictures, Jules Furthman, Whitman Chambers and William Faulkner
end.brief_description: A Martinique charter boat skipper gets mixed up with the underground French resistance operatives during WWII.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: With the code restricting what could be shown, filmmakers began to rely on innuendo to illustrate lust and passion. Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart’s famous whistling scene oozes sexual chemistry with Bacall’s silver-tongued banter.

links.description: A love story set against the backdrop of war and the Great Depression, The World Moves On was the first film to receive the official production seal of approval under the Hays Code (MPPDA Certificate No. 1) in November 1934.

start.title: The Outlaw
start.creator_credit: Howard Hughes, Wallace Grissell, Howard Hughes Productions, RKO Radio Pictures and Jules Furthman
start.brief_description: Newly appointed sheriff Pat Garrett is pleased when his old friend Doc Holliday arrives in Lincoln, New Mexico on the stage. Doc is trailing his stolen horse, and it is discovered in the possession of Billy the Kid. In a surprising turnaround, Billy and Doc become friends. This causes the friendship between Doc and Pat to cool. The odd relationship between Doc and Billy grows stranger when Doc hides Billy at his girl Rio’s place after Billy is shot.

constellations_other.name: My People
constellations_other.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: By the 1960s the production code’s decline was in earnest with Warner Bros. Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf the first film to receive a ‘Suggested for Mature Audiences’ label. New Motion Picture Production Association President Jack Valenti introduced the Film Rating System in November 1968.

constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. links.description: Bogart would redefine his career and create an all new style of shady hero in The Maltese Falcon, considered by many to be the first noir film. Bogart’s detective would be wooed by duplicitous femme fatales yet get by with his wits and ability to hide in the shadows.

links.description: With an illustrative black and white design, dynamic lighting and camera angles, classic noir-esque dialogue and charismatic flawed hero, Nintendo’s Hotel Dusk: Room 215 was clearly inspired by film noir using the genre to great effect in its point and click adventure game.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the Hays Code
constellations_other.description: The Motion Picture Production Code, known as the Hays Code, was a self imposed set of industry guidelines outlining what could and couldn't be shown in Hollywood films. Established in 1930 but not enforced till 1934, the code would eventually be replaced with the film rating system in 1968.

links.description: Howard Hughes pushed the boundaries of the code with The Outlaw. Held up for years by the code’s approval process, the film was completed in 1941 yet not widely released until 1946 with the Hays Office taking issue with the sexualisation of Jane Russell and the marketing focus on her chest.

end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: By charting the production process through his surreal images in In Pictures: A Hollywood Satire, photographer Will Connell satirises the absurd overreach of the studios and highlights their control and coercion.

links.description: The kind of focus by filmmakers on women’s bodies and sexuality, like the marketing of The Outlaw, was the kind of thing that Will Connell’s photo series In Pictures: A Hollywood Satire exposed through surreal images.

links.description: Banned in the UK, pre-code film Red-Headed Woman had it all. A brilliantly clever yet somewhat wicked lead character, comedy and snappy dialogue not to mention premarital sex, attempted murder, marriage breakdown and the original blonde bombshell herself, Jean Harlow.

results.name: Femme fatales to fembots
results.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

key_work.title: Fatal women
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. The archetype can be traced from silent-era star Theda ‘The Vamp’ Bara to Amy Dunne (Rosamund Pike) in Gone Girl.

constellations_primary.name: Femme fatales to fembots

start.title: Metropolis
start.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Erich Pommer and UFA
start.brief_description: A classic early SF story of a dehumanised futuristic society in which the workers toil below the ground for the benefit of an elite who live above. Fascinating sequences are woven into the sentimental story of the romance between the son of the city’s ruler and a saintly girl from below ground.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

end.title: Ex Machina
end.creator_credit: Allon Reich, Andrew Macdonald and Andrew MacDonald
end.brief_description: A young coder wins a competition to spend a week at a private mountain retreat belonging to the world’s largest internet company’s reclusive CEO. But when he arrives, Caleb has to participate in an experiment involving the world’s first true AI.

constellations_other.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_other.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

constellations_other.name: Robots, robots everywhere
constellations_other.description: Steampunk aesthetics, malevolent AI and cybernetic cops push the frontiers of imagination in this Constellation inspired by Dishonored 2.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

links.description: The sexual and dangerous ‘fembot’ trope is seen throughout cinematic history, from Maria in Metropolis to Pris (Darryl Hannah) in Blade Runner to Ava (Alicia Vikander) in Ex-Machina.

start.title: Fatal attraction
start.creator_credit: Adrian Lyne, Sherry Lansing, Stanley R. Jaffe and Paramount Pictures
start.brief_description: Michael Douglas, Glenn Close and Anne Archer star in this gripping, if at times inconsistent thriller. A passionate week-end encounter ends Dan Gallagher’s perfect life. Alex refuses to be a woman scorned and her capacity for revenge and violence is without limit. The conclusion is unforgettably shattering as the nightmare draws to its inevitable “bloody” climax. Glenn Close gives an excellent, terrifying performance as the homicidal Alex as the film grapples with men’s subconscious fears about women.

end.brief_description: While visiting China, an American man falls in love with a young Chinese woman, but he then has second thoughts about the relationship. The plot is a variation of the Madame Butterfly story.

constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

links.description: The opera Madame Butterfly is the soundtrack to Alex’s (Close) affair with a married man. The ‘Butterfly’ is a trope of a subservient woman, which Anna May Wong played in The Toll of the Sea. She’s famous for playing ‘dragon ladies’ similar to the femme fatale.

end.brief_description: John Hughes wrote and and directed this teen farce. Gary and Wyatt are two unpopular geeks in high school who fantasise about having beautiful girlfriends and being the coolest kids in school. Inspired by a clip from the classic film “Frankenstein”, the two decide to try their luck at creating the woman of their dreams. The result is Lisa - beautiful, saucy and the answer to every man’s dream - who becomes a mentor to the two libidinous youths, her mission being to help them get the young women they want. Cast includes: Anthony Michael Hall, Kelly LeBrock, Ilan Mitchell-Smith, Robert Downey Jr. and Bill Paxton.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

links.description: Robotic women often represent men’s desire to control women and reduce them to literal objects. In the 1980s two ‘nerds’ gain popularity when they use computers to create ‘the perfect woman’, who ends up teaching them to respect women.

links.description: The femme fatale is a trope as old as the sirens of Greek mythology. On screen, it can be traced back to silent era ‘vamp’ – a dangerous, sensual vamp that come from The Vampire Theda Bara plays in A Fool There Was.

end.title: The Maltese falcon
end.creator_credit: John Huston, Henry Blanke and Warner Bros Pictures
end.brief_description: In this classic Humphrey Bogart film noir, John Huston sketches a dark, cynical world with painfully deep perception. Sam Spade, Dashiell Hammett’s archetypal private eye, is caught in the desperate search for the jewelled falcon of Malta. Spade’s pursuit of his partner’s killer leads him to a group of individuals who want the black bird: Brigid O’Shaughnessey (Mary Astor), the beautiful femme fatale, cowardly Joel Cairo (Peter Lorre) and pompously inflated Kasper Gutman (Sydney Greenstreet) and as the falcon comes within their reach their intense greed is sharply etched. Huston also wrote the script.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

links.description: A Fool There Was’ sexual ‘vampire’ was a threat to traditional gender roles of the era. So was the femme fatale, who appeared in 1940s cinema after women gained independence during WWII. Mary Astor’s character in The Maltese Falcon was one of the first.

end.title: Fatal attraction
end.creator_credit: Adrian Lyne, Sherry Lansing, Stanley R. Jaffe and Paramount Pictures
end.brief_description: Michael Douglas, Glenn Close and Anne Archer star in this gripping, if at times inconsistent thriller. A passionate week-end encounter ends Dan Gallagher’s perfect life. Alex refuses to be a woman scorned and her capacity for revenge and violence is without limit. The conclusion is unforgettably shattering as the nightmare draws to its inevitable “bloody” climax. Glenn Close gives an excellent, terrifying performance as the homicidal Alex as the film grapples with men’s subconscious fears about women.

links.description: Though most popular in the 1940s, the femme fatale returned in the 1980s. This time they embodied fears about career-minded, financially secure and sexually assertive women, like Alex Forrest (Glenn Close) in Fatal Attraction (1987).

start.brief_description: While visiting China, an American man falls in love with a young Chinese woman, but he then has second thoughts about the relationship. The plot is a variation of the Madame Butterfly story.

end.creator_credit: Kevin Lima, Edward S. Feldman and Walt Disney Pictures
end.brief_description: Based on the novel by Dodie Smith, and a sequel to Disney’s 1996 live-action adaptation of their animated classic, ‘101 Dalmatians’, this live-action film once again features Glenn Close in the role of the over-the-top and rather bizarre Cruella De Vil. After three years in prison Cruella is determined to keep away from animal fur - especially of the doggy kind - but it seems despite all her best intentions, Cruella unwittingly finds herself again embroiled in a ‘haute couture’ situation. Cast includes Ioan Gruffudd, Alice Evans, Tim McInnerny, Ian Richardson, Gerard Depardieu.

end.brief_description: A classic early SF story of a dehumanised futuristic society in which the workers toil below the ground for the benefit of an elite who live above. constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

links.description: Sometimes the femme fatale isn’t even human. In Fritz Lang’s masterpiece Metropolis, the dangerous woman is an android called Maria, who appears in human form as a vampish dancer, and exhibits similar qualities.

start.title: The Good Earth

start.brief_description: Set in pre-revolutionary China, Paul Muni plays Wang Lung, a simple peasant farmer who rises to become a prosperous lord. Luise Rainer won an Academy Award for her portrayal of O-Lan, Wang’s devoted wife, a battered slave who grows into a proud, loyal woman. Based on Pearl S. Buck’s Pulitzer Prize winning novel.

end.title: Shanghai Express
end.creator_credit: Josef von Sternberg, Adolph Zukor and Paramount Pictures
end.brief_description: The lightweight plot - an evacuation by train from Peking to Shanghai - is merely the pretext for one of Sternberg’s most successful pieces of stylization, a fruitful collaboration with cinematographer Lee Garmes (and an uncredited James Wong Howe), and writer Jules Furthman. Dietrich plays Shanghai Lily, a ‘coaster’ (a woman who lives by her wits along the Chinese coast) whose scandalous lifestyle is summed up in the films now classic line, ‘It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily’. Clive Brook’s plays Dietrich’s love interest Captain Donald Harvey, a stuffy Englishman who knew Lily before her infamous lifestyle and is still hurting from her having previously run off on him. Sternberg uses the stop-start cadences of the narrative as a means to evoke the rhythm of the train, while functioning as a kind of time machine confronting the motley group with their pasts as it carries them to their respective fates. However Sternberg’s main point of interest is Dietrich whose status in the film takes on fetishistic proportions, while being gloriously framed and lit in every scene. Cast includes Anna May Wong, Louise Closser Hale, Eugene Pallette, Lawrence Grant. (Awards: Winner, Best Cinematography- Lee Garmes, Academy Awards, 1932)

links.description: After leaving Hollywood for Europe due to being typecast, Anna May Wong starred alongside her rumoured lover, Marlene Dietrich, in Shanghai Express in 1932. Film historians today view her performance as upstaging Dietrich.

start.title: Fearless: the Hunterwali story
start.creator_credit: Riyad Vinci Wadia and Wadia Movietone
start.brief_description: This documentary traces the life of Australian born actress Mary Evans who performed in numerous Indian films of the 1930s and 1940s under the alluring nom-de-plume Fearless Nadia. With her buxom physique, blonde hair and blue eyes Nadia’s roles typically showed her displaying incredible strength and fortitude in the face of marauding forces and wicked villains. Her roles included “Hunterwali” (1935), “Diamond Queen” (1940), “Jungle Princess” (1942), “Tigress” (1948) and “Jungle Queen” (1956), among others. Nadia challenged the traditionally submissive roles played by women in Indian cinema and performed many amazing and dangerous stunts required for the action and swashbuckling genres in which she extensively worked. J.B.H. Wadia (1901-86), a frequent collaborator of Nadia’s, became a master of adventure films as a successful director and producer along with his brother Homi. Features extensive interviews with Fearless Nadia reminiscing upon her life in the cinema; intrepid stuntman and actor John Cavas (aka Cawas) who worked extensively with Nadia; as well as several other Indian filmmaker contemporaries of Nadia. Numerous clips from Nadia’s oeuvre are shown alongside explanations of dangerous stunt work and co-ordination, and technical developments in cinema. With English subtitles.

end.title: Fearless: the Hunterwali story
end.creator_credit: Riyad Vinci Wadia and Wadia Movietone
end.brief_description: This documentary traces the life of Australian born actress Mary Evans who performed in numerous Indian films of the 1930s and 1940s under the alluring nom-de-plume Fearless Nadia. With her buxom physique, blonde hair and blue eyes Nadia’s roles typically showed her displaying incredible strength and fortitude in the face of marauding forces and wicked villains. Her roles included “Hunterwali” (1935), “Diamond Queen” (1940), “Jungle Princess” (1942), “Tigress” (1948) and “Jungle Queen” (1956), among others. Nadia challenged the traditionally submissive roles played by women in Indian cinema and performed many amazing and dangerous stunts required for the action and swashbuckling genres in which she extensively worked. J.B.H. Wadia (1901-86), a frequent collaborator of Nadia’s, became a master of adventure films as a successful director and producer along with his brother Homi. Features extensive interviews with Fearless Nadia reminiscing upon her life in the cinema; intrepid stuntman and actor John Cavas (aka Cawas) who worked extensively with Nadia; as well as several other Indian filmmaker contemporaries of Nadia. Numerous clips from Nadia’s oeuvre are shown alongside explanations of dangerous stunt work and co-ordination, and technical developments in cinema. With English subtitles.

Beautiful Amazon princess Wonder Woman travels to 1940s America disguised as Diana Prince, assistant to handsome but trouble-prone Major Steve Trevor. Using her golden belt, which imbues her with astonishing strength, her bullet-deflecting bracelets, a golden lasso that dispels dishonesty and an invisible supersonic plane, Wonder Woman combats evil.

end.title: The Matrix Reloaded
end.creator_credit: Lana Wachowski, Lilly Wachowski, Kym Barrett, Zach Staenberg, Joel Silver, NPV Entertainment, Silver Pictures, Village Roadshow Pictures, Owen Paterson and Mayumi Arakaki
end.brief_description: Six months after the events depicted in The Matrix, Neo has proved to be a good omen for the free humans, as more and more humans are being freed from the matrix and brought to Zion, the one and only stronghold of the Resistance. Neo himself has discovered his superpowers including super speed, ability to see the codes of the things inside the matrix and a certain degree of pre-cognition. But a nasty piece of news hits the human resistance: 250,000 machine sentinels are digging to Zion and would reach them in 72 hours. As Zion prepares for the ultimate war, Neo, Morpheus and Trinity are advised by the Oracle to find the Keymaker who would help them reach the Source. Meanwhile Neo’s recurrent dreams depicting Trinity’s death have got him worried and as if it was not enough, Agent Smith has somehow escaped deletion, has become more powerful than before and has fixed Neo as his next target.

results.name: What's in a name?
results.description: Pakeezah (1972) star Meena Kumari was not just 'the tragedy queen' of Hindi film – she also wrote poetry under the pseudonym Naaz. From famous families and stage names to gendered disguises, this Constellation explores how women have adopted different names and identities to facilitate their ambition.

end.title: Kill Bill Vol. 1
end.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender, A Band Apart and Miramax Films
end.brief_description: Written and directed by Quentin Tarantino, “Kill Bill Vol. 1” is a tribute to the many hours of martial arts films he must have seen as a fan over his lifetime. Classic elements of cinematographic style and action sequences are included in all their violent glory. The plot centres on a Bride’s (Uma Thurman) quest to exact revenge on those who prevented her from leaving the brutal world of the hired killer. Heavily pregnant and attending her wedding, all present at the church are massacred and she is shot in the head, leaving her in coma for four years. On recovering from the coma, the woman (Thurman) arms herself with a rare sword and goes about killing those who aimed to destroy her. We learn of the history of one of her most challenging opponents through the use of a detailed anime sequence - “The Origin of O-Ren” (Lucy Liu). Many are dead at the end of this film and the woman is only some way to crossing off the five people on her “Death List” - see also “Kill Bill Vol. 2”. Infused with the music, wit and humour of a Tarantino picture, “Kill Bill Vol. 1” is a classic revenge story with all of the requisite action sequences and fine storytelling. Cast includes Vivica A. Fox, Sonny Chiba, Chiaki Kuriyama, Gordon Liu, Michael Parks, Julia Dreyfus, Michael Bowen, Jun Kunimura, Kenji Oba, Yuki Kazamatsuri, James Parks, Daryl Hannah and Michael Madsen. SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB. PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS FILM (ALSO CONTAINING ANIMATION) HAS AN ‘R’ RATING FOR PERSONS OVER THE AGE OF 18 DUE TO THE EXPLICIT VIOLENT NATURE OF ITS CONTENT

end.title: Charlie's angels [DVD]
end.creator_credit: McG, Drew Barrymore, Leonard Goldberg, Nancy Juvonen and Global Entertainment
end.brief_description: This big screen adaptation of the popular 70s TV series sees the return of the beautiful, brilliant and sassy angels who work for billionaire recluse, Charles Townsend. Together with their fellow colleague, Bosley, they are sent to work when an electronic genius, Eric Knox, is kidnapped. They soon discover even bigger problems are at bay when they realise Knox’s latest technology is a system which can monitor voice communication from anywhere in the world. This is an exuberant action comedy which never takes itself seriously, combining modern day themes with elements of 70s cheese. Cast includes: Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore, Lucy Liu, Bill Murray, Sam Rockwell, Tim Curry, Kelly Lynch, Crispin Glover and the voice of John Forsythe as Charlie.

end.title: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time
end.brief_description: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time reveals the genesis of the fantasy land of Hyrule, the origin of the Triforce, and the tale of the first exploits of Princess Zelda and the heroic adventurer Link. Vibrant, real-time 3-D graphics transport you into the fantasy world of Hyrule. Your quest takes you through dense forests and across wind-whipped deserts. Swim raging rivers, climb treacherous mountains, dash on horseback across rolling hills, and delve into dungeons full of creatures that fight to the finish to put an end to your adventures. With immersive graphics, a sweeping story line, swashbuckling adventure, mind-bending puzzles, and a touch of humor, The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time is one of Nintendo’s most epic challenges ever.

links.description: As Drew Barrymore knows, a famous name can be a blessing and a curse. In videogame Ocarina of Time (1998), Princess Zelda realises her famous name makes her a target. She adopts the identity Sheik, posing as a boy to aid the hero, Link, in his quest to save Hyrule.

end.title: Yentl
end.creator_credit: Barbra Streisand, Rusty Lemorande, Barwood Films, Ladbroke Entertainment and United Artists Corporation
end.brief_description: Based on the short story “Yentl, the Yeshiva boy” by Isaac Bashevis Singer, this is the poignant tale of a young European Jewish woman (Barbara Streisand), circa 1904, who disguises herself as a boy in order to pursue her passion for studying holy scripture, an endeavour restricted exclusively to men in orthodox Jewish culture. As the education of women is prohibited in her society, she must keep her identity a secret. The strangely deceptive world this creates poses many challenges for this intrepid character who, in overcoming them, proves that nothing is impossible. The making of this modern classic was a milestone, not only for its main creative force, the legendary Streisand, but for motion picture history. “Yentl” marked the first time that a woman had produced, co-written, directed and starred in a major feature film.

constellations_other.name: What's in a name?

links.description: Gendered disguises like Zelda’s have a long cinematic history. In her directorial debut Yentl (1983), Barbra Streisand’s starred as the eponymous Yentl, a Jewish woman who poses as a boy to study the Talmud, despite initial concerns she was “too feminine” for the role.

end.title: Suspiria [Widescreen]
end.creator_credit: Dario Argento, Claudio Argento and La Seda
end.brief_description: Presented in widescreen, this un-cut version of Dario Argento’s ‘Suspiria’ is the first part (1980’s ‘Inferno’ being the follow up) in an as yet to be complete trilogy called “The Three mothers”. Susy Banyon (Jessica Harper), an American Ballet student travels to Germany to attend the exclusive Tanz Academy in Frieburg. Legend goes that the ancient school was once the residence of a witches coven, headed by an evil and powerful black witch named Mater Suspiriorum (Black Widow). When a series of grisly murders begin to occur at the ballet school, Susy begins to suspect that witchcraft may be involved. Working at the height of his creative powers (following the box office success of 1975’s ‘Deep Red’) Argento raises the level of terror with his trademark blood soaked set pieces by using vibrant colour film stock, abrupt editing, multi-layered sound scapes (including the techno-rock Goblin score) and rapid camera movement. Cast also includes Alida Valli, Udo Kier, Stefania Casini, Joan Bennett, Flavio Bucci, Miguel Bose, Barbara Magnolfi and Susanna Javicoli.

links.description: In Suspiria (2018), Tilda Swinton took gender play like Yentl’s (1983) to its extreme. She played three roles, including 82-year-old therapist Dr. Josef Klemperer – credited to fictional actor Lutz Ebersdorf, to foreground the performance over the shock factor of the casting.

results.name: Controversy and censorship
results.description: In this constellation, we look at the history of censorship in moving image history, from early blaxploitation films to videogames and beyond.

key_work.title: The Godmother of Blaxploitation
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Capturing the frustration and energy of the 1970s, Blaxploitation films created space for Black women to be action stars with top-line credit. Though it was originally coined as a derogatory term, Blaxploitation films like Coffy addressed racial injustice and the civil rights movements of the era.

constellations_primary.name: Controversy and censorship

start.title: Jackie Brown [DVD]
start.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender, Band Apart and Mighty Mighty Afrodite Productions
start.brief_description: Ruthless arms dealer Ordell Robbie (Samuel L. Jackson), who lives with perpetually stoned beach-babe Melanie (Bridget Fonda), teams with his old buddy Louis Gara (Robert De Niro), just released from prison after serving four years for armed robbery. ATF agent Ray Nicolette (Michael Keaton), and cop Mark Dargus (Michael Bowen), bust stewardess Jackie Brown (Pam Grier), who was smuggling money into the country for Ordell. Ordell springs Jackie, but when middle-aged bail bondsman Max Cherry (Robert Forster) picks her up at the jail, he’s attracted to her, and they choose a romantic route with detours. Mistrust and suspicions surface after Jackie pits Ordell and the cops against each other, convincing Ordell that she’s going to double-cross the cops. Adapted from Elmore Leonard’s novel “Rum Punch”, “Jackie Brown” is Tarantino’s homage to Blaxploitation cinema of the 1970s and a tribute to one of its feistiest characters - Pam Grier.

video_links.name: The Chant Of Jimmie Blacksmith Trailer

end.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

links.description: Like Foxy Brown (1974), Australian film The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith (1978) was seized during the UK video nasty panic. Based on the true story of Jimmy Governor, a First Nations man whose experiences of exploitation and racism drove him to murder.

links.description: The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith (1978) experience a brief UK ban but Australia has strict classification laws too – particularly around videogames. end.title: Devotion
end.brief_description:
‘Devotion’ is a first-person atmospheric horror game set in the 1980s Taiwan.

The story centers around a seemingly ordinary family of three that lived in an old apartment complex. Explore the nostalgic house in the 80s where religion plays a significant role in their daily life. When one day the same house that once filled with joy and love had turned into a hell-like nightmare, and by venturing in the haunted and confined space, each puzzle leads you closer to the mysteries nested deep inside.

constellations_other.name: Controversy and censorship

links.description: Videogames can also be censored by platforms, not governments. In 2020, Taiwanese studio Red Candle Games had their first-person horror game Devotion (2019) removed from digital videogame marketplace Steam following controversy over a critical reference to Chinese premier Xi Jinping,

end.title: Brazen Hussies
end.creator_credit: Catherine Dwyer, Rosie Jones, Andrea Foxworthy, Philippa Campey and Film Camp
end.brief_description: BRAZEN HUSSIES reveals for the first time, an exciting and revolutionary chapter in Australian history, the Women’s Liberation Movement (1965 -1975). Interweaving freshly uncovered archival footage, personal photographs, memorabilia and lively personal accounts from activists all around Australia, BRAZEN HUSSIES shows us how a daring and diverse group of women joined forces to defy the status quo, demand equality and create profound social change. These women defined one of the greatest social movements of the 20th Century, at times at great personal cost. This documentary is full of the raw energy and determination that fueled feminism for the next 50 years.

A gripping and profound examination of race, gender, intersectionality, and the toll sexual abuse takes on survivors and on society at large.

end.title: The Watermelon Woman
end.creator_credit: Cheryl Dunye, Alexandra Juhasz, Barry Swimar and Dancing Girl Productions
end.brief_description: One of the first feature films made by an African American lesbian, this ‘mockumentary’ ostensibly investigates the life of a forgotten black actress from the thirties known only as, the Watermelon Woman. Filmmaker Cheryl Dunye plays herself as a video shop employee and budding film director who begins researching the actress with a view to making a movie based upon her life story. As she uncovers archival footage and conducts interviews with archivists, scholars (played in a series of cameos by real-life experts including Camille Paglia) and women who lived in the Philadelphia area in the thirties, Dunye pieces together a previously unacknowledged history of African American lesbian life in the thirties. She finds that the Watermelon Woman was a nightclub singer named Fae Richards who was the lover of the white Hollywood female director, Martha Page. Meanwhile, Dunye herself falls in love with Diana (Guinevere Turner), one of the customers that frequent the video store where she works. Their passionate relationship allows her to explore her own feelings around interracial romance. The film functions on two levels, as a wry, irreverent look at contemporary black lesbian culture, and as a critique of official narratives that have erased this culture from history. While Dunye ultimately reveals the Watermelon Woman as a fiction, she points out that “sometimes you have to create you own history”.

links.description: Like Disclosure (2020), The Watermelon Woman (1997) considers erasure and marginalisation in film. Director Cheryl Dunye uses autofiction to consider how the lack of Black women & Black lesbians in film history impedes her ability to imagine the future of Black lesbian filmmaking.
